data.title: Pantheon Rise of the Fallen: Everything coming in the December update
data.description: The recent dev diary for Pantheon Rise of the Fallen highlights everything new coming in the December 2025 update.
data.creator: Mayank Singh Rathour
data.content: The recent dev diary for Pantheon Rise of the Fallen highlights everything new coming in the December 2025 update. This time, it‚Äôs focused on mounts and the taming system, providing players with an easy way to travel around. However, that‚Äôs not all, as there is a deeper progression within, allowing you to tame and trade a variety of mounts. With this update, the devs aim to lay the foundation for the mount system, providing players with something new to grind for. The future update promises the ability to name, gear, or trade mounts, but let‚Äôs find out more about what's coming in the initial mounts and taming update for Pantheon Rise of the Fallen. Everything new coming in Pantheon Rise of the Fallen‚Äôs December update Mounts With the December update, you‚Äôll be able to tame a variety of creatures in the game and convert them into mounts. Most games feature them as a means of traveling, but in Pantheon Rise of the Fallen, mounts come in different rarities and stat spreads. Taming is a new ability that will help you capture mounts. You‚Äôll get it as part of an introductory quest after reaching at least level 20 to gain access. You can use the ability once you're close enough to the mount. However, there are several steps to complete the process. The skill consumes Endurance, so investing in that stat will make the process much easier. Creatures also have ‚ÄòWill‚Äô that increases taming cost. Higher rarity creatures also have a higher amount of Will, making the process a lot more tedious. Additionally, during the process, the creature will become hostile and will attack the tamer, meaning you‚Äôll also need to improve your HP and defense to survive the next ten seconds. Stables Stables are where you register your mount. The process is necessary to permanently own your mounts, as even after taming, you can lose them due to various reasons. Once you tame a creature, ride it to the nearest stable within the villages or towns. This process is necessary, as teleporting directly before reaching the stable will result in you losing the mount. Note that you can take an unregistered mount into an adjacent zone, but you can lose it if it takes too much damage or you are forcibly dismounted. Luckily, stables are available everywhere. They also let you keep track of and manage all your mounts. Additionally, you can also pay a small fee to return a registered mount to the stable while traveling in the open world. This feature will be useful if you find a higher rarity creature, as you can only have one active mount on the field. Check out other related guides and features:.

data.title: Why the mirrorless camera I recommend to most beginners isn't a Sony or Canon (and it's on sale)
data.description: The Nikon Z5 II is a great camera for aspiring photographers to transition into the professional photography realm.
data.creator: ZDNET
data.content: Follow ZDNET: Add us as a preferred source on Google. Capturing great photography has gotten easier and easier these days, thanks to the trusty smartphones we all carry in our pockets. However, there are times when a smartphone's capabilities will not be sufficient. Instead, opt for a dedicated, pro-grade camera, such as the Nikon Z5 II. No need to lean on AI smarts or computational photography, just lean on the right tool for the right job. Also: Cyber Monday deals are huge in 2025: Shop my favorite deals from Amazon, Best Buy, Lowe's & more The team at Nikon was kind enough to loan me its Z5 II for a couple of weeks to see just how well its mid-tier camera body will hold up for day-to-day photography as well as professional scenarios. It's been a lot of fun trying out the Z5 II. Allow me to share my experience with you. The basics you should know The Nikon Z5 II is a 24. 5-megapixel full-frame camera capable of grabbing images at 14 frames per second while using the mechanical shutter. But this is the age of mirrorless cameras. Photographers can now shoot with an electronic shutter. The Z5 II allows for 30 frames per second capture in electronic shutter mode. Making it extremely easy to capture action shots. The Z5 II also captures video in 4K up to 60 frames per second and HD resolution at 120 frames per second. It also includes dual SD card slots for those days when the photoshoot runs really long. Using the Z5 II on a professional job Granted I spend most of my time in front of the camera more so this year than behind the it, but from time to time I still shoot high school sports and portraits. I tried the Z5 II in a portrait environment, then really challenged it in not only a sports environment, but a low-light, fast-paced football game. Shooting with controlled lighting in a studio setting was a breeze, as is the case with most cameras these days. As someone who's accustomed to shooting in manual mode, I encountered no problems adjusting the shutter speed, ISO, or aperture on the Z5 II because the dials and controls are well-positioned to work with almost anyone holding the camera body. Also: I fell in love with a $2,000 mirrorless camera that puts design and simplicity over everything else I'm a Canon shooter because the ergonomics on Canon bodies best fit my large hands, but this offering from Nikon is a worthy mention in terms of ergonomics, in addition to its image quality. While shooting a football game, I knew the Z5 II would be challenged. A few variables were stacked against it. First, the football field was poorly lit for photography at higher shutter speeds. Secondly, Nikon loaned me its 24-50mm "kit" lens. This has lower-quality glass as well as a less-than-ideal aperture at f/6. 3. Due to these variables, the ISO had to be set higher than 6400 to capture any usable frames. Having an ISO above 1600 can lead to image noise if the camera isn't properly stabilized during image capture. With that said, the images from the Z5 II weren't bad. I wish I could have utilized a tighter focal length, but the images were definitely usable. The image noise was low. The quality was strong. The autofocus was outstanding. Football players running the ball present a lot of challenges. First, they're moving really quickly -- toward you. Also: Microsoft's new AI agents create your Word, Excel, and PowerPoint projects now Secondly, the lighting is usually low. From the camera settings, you'll need a shutter speed that's fast enough to limit motion blur and an autofocus that will keep up with the subject as it moves quickly into and through your framing. As you can see in the image sequence, the Z5 II maintained great focus on the runner with the football and exhibited minimal motion blur, even at a 1/250-second shutter speed. The runner ran past me and was still in focus. Again, I wish I had a more professional lens attached to this camera body, but this was a fun attempt. Some may notice how green the grass looks in this image. This is not due to the color science of the Z5 II. The grass is truly that green this time of year in Northern California. ZDNET's buying advice The Nikon Z5 II mirrorless camera body is available online for $1,596. You can add the kit lens for a total of $1,896. This is a fair price. Even though you're paying for a photography kit that's roughly the same price as your trusty smartphone, it doesn't even send text messages. What you lack in telephony capability, you gain in true photography prowess. The full-frame sensor will perform significantly better than your smartphone, both in low-light and well-lit conditions. You'll get a true 24. 5-megapixel image with vibrant colors. Not faux "40-megapixels" offered by smartphones due to pixel binning. My only criticism of the Z5 II is that the image sensor isn't protected when changing lenses. Ideally, a shutter curtain should cover the sensor when it's not in use. That's not the case with this camera body. I would recommend this camera to photography enthusiasts looking to expand their photography portfolio and take on serious professional work. Just add a prime lens to the Z-mount and start shooting.

data.title: E-Auto unter 17.000 Euro: Verschlafen die deutschen Autobauer den n√§chsten E-Trend?
data.description: In Asien boomen erschwingliche E-Autos mit Akku-Wechsel. W√§hrend SAIC, NIO und Perodua den Massenmarkt erschlie√üen, ignorieren deutsche Autobauer den Trend und stecken weiter in ihrer Premiumfalle.
data.creator: wallstreet-online.de
data.content: P√ºnktlich zum Weihnachtsgesch√§ft hat Perodua aus Malaysia am Montag sein erstes Elektroauto QV-E auf den Markt gebracht, das ab 80. 000 Ringgit (rund 16. 740 Euro) kosten soll. Die Botschaft ist klar: E-Mobilit√§t soll f√ºr die Mittelschicht funktionieren. Eine Besonderheit ist, dass die Batterie separat geleast wird nach dem Prinzip "Battery as a Service". Die Leasingkosten kommen also noch dazu, der gro√üe Vorteil ist aber die enorme Schnelligkeit, mit der die Akkus ausgetauscht werden (3-5 Minuten) und, dass sich K√§ufer nie wieder um das Thema k√ºmmern m√ºssen. Sie werden f√ºr die gesamte Laufzeit des Fahrzeugs zur Verf√ºgung gestellt. Die Kunden zahlen weniger in der Anschaffung, erhalten eine Batterie mit bis zu 445 Kilometern Reichweite und m√ºssen sich um Alterung oder Restwert kaum sorgen. Der Batterietausch boomt in Asien l√§ngst im Massenmarkt. In China betreiben Hersteller wie NIO, SAIC und Geely und Energieunternehmen ein dichtes Netz an Wechselstationen, das t√§glich zehntausende Fahrzeuge bedient. NIO hat den Vorgang des Batterietauschs nahezu perfektioniert und macht ihn in drei bis f√ºnf Minuten m√∂glich. Auch in Taiwan funktioniert das Modell allerdings im Zweiradsegment: Dort tauschen Hunderttausende Rollerfahrer ihre Akkus an rund um die Uhr ge√∂ffneten Stationen. In Indien wiederum entsteht ein eigenes √ñkosystem f√ºr austauschbare Batterien bei Tuk-Tuks, Lieferfahrzeugen und Low-Cost-E-Scootern. Kurz: In gro√üen Teilen Asiens ist Battery Swapping keine Zukunftsvision mehr, sondern Alltag. Lesen Sie auch wallstreetONLINE RedaktionBis 1. 500 km Reichweite Deutsche Autobauer verschlafen schon wieder Mega-Trend! Volkswagen, BMW und Mercedes-Benz haben bislang kein einziges Serienmodell mit Akkuwechsel angek√ºndigt. Es gibt weder technische Plattformen daf√ºr noch Infrastrukturpl√§ne, geschweige denn Kooperationen. W√§hrend chinesische Anbieter ihre Swap-Stationen sogar anderen Herstellern √∂ffnen, halten die deutschen Marken am klassischen Konzept fest: Schnellladen statt Tauschen, Eigentumsbatterie statt Abo-Modell. Von "Technologieoffenheit" keine Spur. Auch mit Blick auf die Erschwinglichkeit der E-Autos geht Deutschland andere Wege. Die quasi parallel zu Perodua vorgestellten Modelle umfassen den BMW iX3 Neue Klasse (Grundpreis 68. 900 Euro), den Audi A6 e-tron (ab 77. 250 Euro) und den Porsche Macan Electric (ab 80. 700 Euro). Dass die Konzentration auf die Wohlhabendsten auf Dauer nicht gut gehen kann, h√§tte eigentlich klar sein m√ºssen. Immerhin gab es zuletzt erste Anzeichen f√ºr ein Umdenken. Mercedes verabschiedete sich k√ºrzlich von seiner Luxus-Strategie. Und Volkswagen k√ºndigte f√ºr 2026 den ID. 2all an, der unter 25. 000 Euro kosten soll. Im Jahr darauf soll unter Umst√§nden dann ein ID. 1 herauskommen, der weniger als 20. 000 Euro kostet. Sp√§t, aber hoffentlich nicht zu sp√§t. Dass die deutschen Hersteller beim Batterietausch nicht mitspielen, hat auch strukturelle Gr√ºnde. Zun√§chst fehlt ihnen die technische Standardisierung, die Swapping √ºberhaupt erst sinnvoll macht. Deutsche Fahrzeugplattformen sind vielf√§ltig, Batterien unterschiedlich verbaut, die Designs zu ausdifferenziert, um ein einheitliches Wechselmodul einzuf√ºhren. Dar√ºber hinaus scheuen die Autobauer die Investitionen in ein eigenes Tauschnetz, denn daf√ºr w√§ren gro√üe Vorleistungen n√∂tig und das in einem Markt, der in Europa noch v√∂llig unerschlossen ist. Hinzu kommt ein gesch√§ftspolitischer Aspekt: Die Batterie ist heute ein zentraler Werttreiber im Auto. W√ºrde sie aus dem Produkt herausgel√∂st und in ein Miet- oder Abo-Modell √ºberf√ºhrt, verl√∂ren die Fahrzeugbauer einen Teil ihrer Marge an Infrastrukturanbieter. Und schlie√ülich steckt hinter der Zur√ºckhaltung auch ein St√ºck Markenidentit√§t: Die deutsche Autoindustrie hat sich jahrelang √ºber Premium, Reichweite und hochpreisige Modelle definiert. Ein Konzept wie Battery Swapping wirkt dagegen pragmatisch, kostensensibel und stark auf den Massenmarkt ausgerichtet genau der Bereich, den deutsche Autokonzerne lange vernachl√§ssigt haben. W√§hrend in Asien also erschwingliche E-Autos mit Akku-Abo und schnellem Tausch zur Normalit√§t werden, klammern sich deutsche Hersteller an das Ideal des technisch aufgeladenen Oberklasseprodukts. Der Fehler ist bekannt: Wer nur nach oben denkt, √ºbersieht den Massenmarkt von unten. Aber genau dort entscheidet sich, wie die Mobilit√§t der Zukunft wirklich aussieht. Autor: Ingo Kolf, wallstreetONLINE Redaktion Die Jahresendrallye rollt an nicht bei Nvidia, Palantir & Co.

data.title: Unzufriedenheit mit dem Staat entsteht in der Kommune
data.description: Fehlende Kitapl√§tze, marode Infrastruktur: Die Unzufriedenheit von Menschen mit der Politik entsteht meist da, wo sie leben und wirkt sich dann auf ihre Haltung zum Staat aus.
data.creator: ZDFheute
data.content: ZDFheute: Welchen Effekt hat es auf die B√ºrgerinnen und B√ºrger, wenn sie in einer armen Kommune leben? Stefan Marschall: Wir wissen, dass sich die Menschen sehr stark mit ihrer Kommune identifizieren, und wenn es dort Probleme gibt, hat das Auswirkungen auf ihre Gesamthaltung zum Staat und der eigenen Heimat. Es ist also so, dass das, was man als staatliche Leistung bezeichnet, zuallererst auf kommunaler Ebene wahrgenommen wird. ZDFheute: Unterscheiden die Menschen denn √ºberhaupt zwischen den Ebenen Bundes-, Landes- und Kommunalpolitik? Marschall: Eher nicht, f√ºr die Menschen ist nicht entscheidend, wer zust√§ndig ist, das ist eher eine rechtliche Frage. Den Menschen ist es egal, ob der Bund, das Land oder ihre Kommune zust√§ndig sind. F√ºr sie ist einfach wichtig, dass der Staat leistungsf√§hig ist. T√ºbingens Oberb√ºrgermeister Boris Palmer: "Kommunen fahren gegen die Wand" . ist Professor f√ºr Politikwissenschaft an der Heinrich-Heine-Universit√§t D√ºsseldorf mit dem Schwerpunkt "Politisches System Deutschlands". Quelle: HHU D√ºsseldorf ZDFheute: Wenn also in meiner Kommune Stra√üen oder Schulen dauerhaft marode sind, √§ndert das mein grunds√§tzliches Verh√§ltnis zum Staat? Marschall: Wenn die Menschen denken, die Politik k√ºmmert sich nicht, dann zweifeln diese Menschen h√§ufig insgesamt an der staatlichen Leistungsf√§higkeit. ZDFheute: Gibt es ein Ungerechtigkeitsempfinden bei den Menschen, wenn sie sehen in meiner Kommune sind Geb√ºhren und Abgaben h√∂her als in den Nachbarkommunen? Marschall: Die Menschen beobachten schon sehr genau, was in anderen Kommunen passiert. Viele kennen ja Leute aus den Nachbarkommunen und man kann die Abgaben und Geb√ºhren ja sehr gut vergleichen. Und so kann ein deutlicher Eindruck entstehen, wenn man merkt, in der einen Kommune werden bestimmte Leistungen nicht mehr erbracht, zum Beispiel Schwimmb√§der oder Bibliotheken schlie√üen. Diese Vergleiche k√∂nnen dazu f√ºhren, dass Frustration entsteht. Schwimmbad-Sanierung: Wer zahlt die Kosten? Kommunen in Finanznot: Wo das Geld dringend n√∂tig ist ZDFheute: Viele Kommunen sind ja enorm hoch verschuldet. Ist es durch Sparen eigentlich m√∂glich, wieder auf einen gr√ºnen Zweig zu kommen? Marschall: Die Verschuldung ist in vielen Kommunen so massiv, die Spielr√§ume sind v√∂llig eingeschr√§nkt. Das f√ºhrt dazu, dass Kommunalpolitiker vielerorts eigentlich kaum noch Spielr√§ume haben. Oft ist es so, dass nur noch die Pflichtaufgaben erf√ºllt werden k√∂nnen, es ist eine Art Mangelverwaltung. Finanzreport: Kommunen rutschen ins Rekordminus Am Ende geht es auf der kommunalen Ebene dann nur noch um Notverwaltung, nicht mehr um Gestaltung.

data.title: Zarzuela ve inoportuno e innecesario el mensaje en v√≠deo de Juan Carlos I dirigido a los j√≥venes
data.description: La Casa del Rey no considera "ni necesario ni oportuno" el mensaje del rey Juan Carlos I difundido mediante un v√≠deo que desde esta ma√±ana circula por las redes sociales en el que se dirige a los j√≥venes para pedirles que apoyen a su hijo, el rey Felipe VI, y del cual no ten√≠an conocimiento en el Palacio de la Zarzuela. Fuentes de Zarzuela se han expresado en estos t√©rminos tras comprobar la difusi√≥n que est√° alcanzando del v√≠deo, que puede reproducirse desde la plataforma YouTube y en el cual el rey em√©rito aparece solo, sentado en una silla, con una gran bandera nacional ondeando detr√°s de √©l. Con este "mensaje para los j√≥venes espa√±oles" el padre del jefe del Estado, que desde hace a√±os reside en Abu Dhabi, ruega que respalden a su hijo en su "duro trabajo" de "unir a todos los espa√±oles". Y a√±ade: "Quiero que sep√°is que vuestros padres, vuestros abuelos y muchos espa√±oles unidos conseguimos hacer una Transici√≥n ejemplar, dar un cambio a este pa√≠s en unas circunstancias muy complejas en las que todos tuvimos que esforzarnos y arriesgar". Eso s√≠, reafirma que "con la generosidad y el esfuerzo de todos logramos que este pa√≠s sea lo que hoy es". Precisamente la difusi√≥n de las im√°genes se produce en v√≠speras de la aparici√≥n en Espa√±a de su libro Reconciliaci√≥n, sus memorias ya publicadas en Francia. De hecho, Juan Carlos ha hecho referencia a esta publicaci√≥n, de la que asegura que el objetivo es transmitir la historia reciente de Espa√±a "sin distorsiones interesadasLa monarqu√≠a ha jugado un papel esencial en toda esta Transici√≥n, una posici√≥n institucional y de relaciones en las que hemos conseguido conectar a Espa√±a con el resto del mundo", a√±ade. Zarzuela remarca, tras confirmar que no sab√≠an nada de este mensaje, que tampoco entiende cu√°les son los objetivos que con √©l busca el rey em√©rito. El v√≠deo dura apenas un minuto y medio y su autenticidad ha sido confirmada a EFE por fuentes del entorno del rey Juan Carlos.

data.description: By WILLIAM CLARK Residents and Monmouth University students gathered on the Long Branch beach recently to etch a 156-foot sand art message aimed at raising awareness of how land thousands of miles away impacts New Jersey. Jackson Smith of the Alaskan Wilderness League led efforts to push awareness of protecting land in the arctic. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs [.].
data.creator: William Clark
data.content: By WILLIAM CLARK Residents and Monmouth University students gathered on the Long Branch beach recently to etch a 156-foot sand art message aimed at raising awareness of how land thousands of miles away impacts New Jersey. Jackson Smith of the Alaskan Wilderness League led efforts to push awareness of protecting land in the arctic. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the last truly wild places,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs roughly the size of South Carolina.‚Äù The refuge is home to polar bears, caribou and holds migratory birds that come to New Jersey. The refuge is also the land of native tribes. Smith said any changes to the arctic environment speeds up climate change worldwide. Conservation efforts and protective status does not just help Alaska but everyone, Smith said. The art on the beach helped draw people into the group‚Äôs efforts to sign and spread petitions and raise awareness of the cause. Long Branch, just on the edge of Representative Chris Smith‚Äôs district, was an ideal place for the exercise, Smith said. Although Smith is a Republican, the effort to protect spaces crosses party lines, Jackson Smith said. ‚ÄúThe arctic is too precious to drill,‚Äù the organizer said. For an hour and a half, volunteers etched the words into the sand while volunteers spoke with people passing by, urging them to join the actions the group has facilitated. Smith said the group received extensive appreciation for their effort from those they spoke to. The sand message was a new medium to get the word out. The first time endeavor was successful, Smith said. Over the span they used small shovels and other basic tools to ensure it was straight and mostly in a shared style. Overhead shots taken with a drone allowed for the best perspective. Smith said Long Branch is just one of many efforts that take place around New Jersey and the country. They have linked up with the Audubon Society and Sierra Club chapters to reach as wide an audience as possible. More information on the organization and ways to help support the cause can be found on defendthearctic. org. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a no brainer,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not really a downside.‚Äù.

data.title: Milk Recall Issued After Cleaning Agent Contamination‚ÄîCheck Your Fridge
keywords: prairie farms gallon fat free milk
data.description: Milk Recall Issued After Cleaning Agent Contamination‚ÄîCheck Your Fridge
data.creator: Michele Laufik
data.content: Check your fridge. Prairie Farms is recalling some of its fat-free milk products that may be contaminated with a food-grade cleaning agent, which can lead to illness, according to the U. S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The recall affects Prairie Farms Gallon Fat Free Milk, produced at the company's Dubuque, Iowa, facility, and distributed to Woodman's stores in Illinois and Wisconsin. Per the FDA, only a specific segment of the December 8 production run was impacted. To identify the product, look for a DEC08 code date and PLT19-145 plant code. The containers also have a timestamp of between 17: 51 and 21: 23 and UPC 7273023117. The company was made aware of the potential quality concern on November 24. An investigation was initiated as soon as the issue was brought to light, and all affected products were removed from store shelves. Although the recalled milk is no longer available for purchase, it may still be in consumers' refrigerators. According to the FDA, approximately 320 gallons of the milk were sold before Prairie Farms discovered the contamination issue. If you purchased the recalled milk, don't consume it. Instead, dispose of it or return it to the store for a refund. com.

data.title: From Field to Backend: The New Regula 7320 Bridges On-the-Go Verification and Centralized Identity Management
data.description: RESTON, Va., Dec. 01, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Regula, a global developer of forensic devices and identity verification (IDV) solutions, unveils the new <a.
data.creator: Business Insider
data.content: RESTON, Va., Dec. 01, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Regula, a global developer of forensic devices and identity verification (IDV) solutions, unveils the new Regula 7320 mobile document reader a compact device designed to solve one of the industry‚Äôs most persistent challenges: the lack of a reliable, fully autonomous, and seamlessly integrated solution for identity verification outside stationary checkpoints. In the field, verification workflows often remain fragmented. Officers must manually re-enter or transfer data, operate with limited power or connectivity, and rely on tools that do not integrate into centralized systems. All this creates delays, inconsistencies, and security gaps. The new Regula 7320 eliminates these issues by bringing border-grade verification, full autonomy, and native ecosystem integration to any location even without network access. Built for professionals in high-risk and high-security sectors from border control and road police to transport security and regulated industries like gambling or car rental the Regula 7320 performs the full identity verification on the spot. Regula 7320 mobile document reader ensures the most trustworthy identity verification even in remote locations Designed for critical operations The Regula 7320 is a new model of mobile document reader that adds more autonomy, power, and interoperability to support even the most demanding scenarios. With border-grade performance and seamless infrastructure integration, the Regula 7320 enables teams to: Verify in various conditions and locations: Perform full document verification (including RFID reading and validation), facial matching, and fingerprint capture in the field, ensuring high reliability even in remote or restricted zones. This eliminates manual re-entry, enables instant processing of cases, and ensures every identity record is logged and consistent. The result: faster decision-making, fewer errors, and end-to-end automation across the entire identity lifecycle. Build seamless environments: Integrate with existing Regula infrastructure or third-party databases for automated AML (anti-money laundering) or PEP (politically exposed persons) checks, data extraction, and reporting, thus minimizing manual work and complex integrations. Technical excellence The Regula 7320 is built for those who can‚Äôt compromise on accuracy or reliability. Its new architecture merges powerful optics, optimized lighting, and extended power capacity to ensure uncompromised verification performance. High-resolution imaging: High-resolution visible-light and 8 MP infrared (IR) cameras deliver forensic-level detail, allowing officers to detect even the smallest traces of forgery or alteration in IDs. Forensic-grade verification accuracy: Optimized UV (ultra-violet) color rendering enables capturing laboratory-grade UV images even under normal ambient light, while a dedicated IR algorithm prevents overexposure and preserves fine detail. These enhancements deliver field-ready automated document authenticity checks comparable to those of a stationary forensic workstation. Extended autonomy: Powered by Regula‚Äôs in-house authenticator with an 11, 000 mAh battery, which can be recharged directly from a high-capacity smartphone, the device provides longer runtimes without recharging, which is essential for field operations. Offline resilience: When connectivity is unavailable, all verified data is securely stored on the device and automatically synchronized with central systems once the connection is restored, ensuring continuity and compliance. ‚ÄúThe Regula 7320 turns field verification from an isolated task into part of an integrated ecosystem. By merging document, biometric, and data verification into one connected workflow, it enables organizations to cut costs, reduce verification times, and strengthen trust across every touchpoint of the identity lifecycle. This upgrade also empowers organizations to address long-standing challenges like limited mobility, fragmented tools, and complex integrations,‚Äù says Alex Lewanowicz, Director of Hardware Engineering at Regula. To learn more about the latest model of the mobile document reader Regula 7320, please visit Regula‚Äôs website. About Regula Regula is a global developer of forensic devices and identity verification solutions. With our 30+ years of experience in forensic research and the most comprehensive library of document templates in the world, we create breakthrough technologies for document and biometric verification. Our hardware and software solutions allow over 1, 000 organizations and 80 border control authorities globally to provide top-notch client service without compromising safety, security, or speed. Regula has been recognized in the 2025 Gartner¬Æ Magic Quadrant‚Ñ¢ for Identity Verification. Learn more at www. regulaforensics. com. A photo accompanying this announcement is available at.
